CONTROL 

  
 (Eds: INSERTS new grafs 6-8 bgng, Even though ..., with background
on DeLay trying to salvage a bill; Pickup 6th graf pvs, The
maneuvering ...; subs second reference to Hastert in 2nd take to
conform.) TWO SIDES LOCKED IN FIERCE FIGHT FOR SWING VOTES ON GUN(nk) 
 By ALISON MITCHELL and FRANK BRUNI   
 c.1999 N.Y. Times News Service   

   WASHINGTON _ As the House prepared for a high-stakes, heavily
lobbied debate on youth violence and guns, President Clinton and
pro-gun forces vied fiercely Tuesday for the votes of a critical
group of lawmakers from swing districts who could decide the
outcome of gun control measures.

   With the contentious debate fracturing both parties in the
House, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., was working closely with Rep.
Tom DeLay, the majority whip from Texas, on an amendment that would
water down a provision passed by the Senate requiring background
checks on all buyers at gun shows.

   A confidant Dingell, whose victory would be a blow to the
president and the Democratic House leadership, predicted that he
had enough votes to prevail when the final gun control votes come
on Thursday. ``We will win,'' Dingell said.

   But the gun control issue has proven remarkably fluid and
unpredictable this spring, and gun control advocates were not
conceding the fight.

   Beyond that, DeLay warned that the measure Dingell was
sponsoring might run into trouble. Republicans allied with DeLay
said they were concerned that conservatives might not rally around
him to vote for Dingell's amendment because they oppose any
restrictions at all on firearms.

   Even though Speaker Dennis Hastert has said Republican leaders
will allow gun control to be a vote of conscience for members,
DeLay has been instrumental in fashioning the structure of the
upcoming debate and the various gun control measures coming to the
floor.

   He met last week with Dingell and on Monday with aides to some
Republican moderates. His allies say DeLay is trying to pass some
modest gun control measure to keep Hastert, who virtually promised
some gun control, from another embarrassing defeat.

   Indeed, Republicans said party leaders implored them Tuesday
night to hold together across the next few days and pass some kind
of a consensus bill rather than risk looking like a do-nothing
Congress. Democrats, however, charge DeLay is really trying to doom
any serious restrictions on firearms.

   The maneuvering was part of an intensifying fight for votes, as
well as a public relations drive by both parties seeking to appeal
to suburban parents stricken by a horrific series of school
shootings.

   Throughout the day both Clinton and a series of Republicans held
competing news conferences on gun control and Republican efforts to
regulate violence in entertainment. Both portray them as issues of
protecting children.

   Clinton appeared in the White House Rose Garden surrounded by
female members of Congress from both parties to rally support for
an amendment by Rep. Carolyn McCarthy, D-N.Y., that would counter
Dingell's measure and is modeled after the Senate legislation on
gun shows.

   In a pointed appeal to suburban women, Clinton cast gun control
as a women's issue, saying, ``Women who belong to both parties in
America, all over this country, have been in the forefront of this
fight. They care about it as mothers, as sisters, as daughters, as
citizens of this country.''

   He also implored lawmakers not to heed the National Rifle
Association. ``Once again the gun lobby is resisting with all its
might,'' Clinton said. ``Once again, we're battling not just for
the safety of our families but the soundness of our democracy.''

   For their part, Republicans were trying to shift the focus from
gun control to cultural issues that they said were more responsible
for youth violence. Late Monday, in a surprise maneuver, they
decided to bring two separate bills to the floor _ one on social
and entertainment issues and the other simply on gun control.

   Tuesday, they highlighted measures ranging from federal
permission to post the Ten Commandments in schools to criminal
penalties for adults who allow children access to entertainment
that Republicans described as ``obscenely violent.''

   Rep. Jo Ann Emerson, R-Mo., cast youth violence as an issue of
culture, and said violent material makes it no surprise that
teen-agers ``plan mass murders instead of graduation parties.''

   But even some Republicans were opposed to some of the directions
their party was taking. ``This is a big government solution to a
problem that government can actually do little to solve,'' said
Rep. Mark Foley, R-Fla., at a news conference.

   On the table in front of him were videos that he said minors
would be prohibited from watching under a key Republican proposal,
including ``Schindler's List,'' ``Lawrence of Arabia,'' ``Mission
Impossible'' and ``Home Alone.''

   nn

   Tuesday night, after a closed-door party caucus, Republicans
were still trying to decide which of nearly 200 measures relating
to gun control and youth violence to allow to the floor for a
debate expected to last 15 hours over two days.

   Republicans said they were leaning toward allowing about 40
amendments on entertainment, culture and law enforcement _
including one on school prayer and the one allowing the Ten
Commandments to be posted in schools.

   But it was the gun control measures that were the focus of the
heaviest pressure.

   House Minority Leader Dick Gephardt of Missouri accused the
Republicans of seeking to rig House procedures in their favor.
``This is not a legislative process,'' he said in a letter to
Hastert, ``it is a deliberate effort to give gun control opponents
every advantage while depriving gun control advocates of vital
information.''

   The House is expected to take up several competing versions of
the measure on background checks at gun shows. It is also to
consider requirements for child safety devices on new handguns, a
raise in the minimum age for all purchases of handguns to 21 from
18, a ban on the import of high capacity ammunition clips and new
restrictions on the possession of semiautomatic rifles.

   Several versions of each of these provisions have been proposed
by an array of lawmakers, some stronger than others. As of Tuesday
night, Republicans appeared likely to let to the floor a Republican
version of the child safety device measure that is less stringent
than the Democrats were proposing. But they were looking to allow
the Democratic version of the ban on imported ammunition clips to
the floor.

   The National Rifle Association had about a dozen lobbyists
working Capitol Hill against the stricter gun control alternatives
while Hand Gun Control, a gun control group, had set up phone banks
to urge gun control advocates to call Congress. Both sides have
also been running radio ads in recent days.

   Unlike in the Senate, where the breadth of a lawmaker's
constituency leads to a broad view, House members represent
smaller, more homogeneous areas. This makes geography destiny when
it comes to gun control.

   So representatives from the cities and their nearby suburbs
generally vote for gun control, including most Democrats and at
least 20 to 30 Republicans. Southerners as well as lawmakers from
the western mountain states and rural areas generally vote against
stringent gun restrictions, including most Republicans and 30 to 40
Democrats.

   Neither Republican nor Democratic party leaders were trying to
make the renegades vote with their party, because of the
recognition that they were making the vote they needed to represent
their district and keep their seat.

   Instead, the bulk of the lobbying attention was focusing on a
particular group of House members caught in a vise: Republicans and
Democrats whose congressional districts encompass both rural areas
and suburbs, forcing them to balance the views of avid gun owners
against those of increasingly militant suburban parents fearful of
school violence.

   These 35 or so people _ perhaps 20 Republicans and 15 Democrats
_ will be key to deciding whether the House passes the same kinds
of gun control measures as the Senate did last month or waters down
the restrictions by defeating some of them and putting in place a
less stringent requirement for criminal background checks on
weapons sales at gun shows.

   As of Tuesday night, Dingell was saying he thought he could draw
a total of more than 40 Democrats to his side, and the gun control
advocates were fearing that as many as 45 Democrats would bolt from
the party. Republican strategists said they thought no more than 35
Republicans would defect to support Mrs. McCarthy's gun show
amendment.
